title: Understanding Relative Error
text: When multiplying two measurements, the errors associated with each measurement affect the final result. It's important to understand how these errors combine.

title: What is Relative Error?
text: Relative error is the ratio of the absolute error to the measured value, often expressed as a percentage. It provides a sense of how significant the error is relative to the size of the measurement.

title: Combining Relative Errors
text: When multiplying two measurements, the relative errors of each measurement are added together to find the relative error of the product.

title: Calculating Relative Error in Multiplication
text: If you have two measurements, A and B, with relative errors of 5% and 3% respectively, what is the relative error of the product $$A B$$?

title: Why Add Relative Errors?
text: Adding relative errors accounts for the combined uncertainty in both measurements, ensuring that the final result reflects the potential variability from both sources.
